In [2, 18, 19], auction mechanisms are proposed for the case where there is only one spectrum block to allocate. LSAA [18] is the first auction mechanism which was proposed as a candidate for the LSA context. It performs well in terms of social welfare assuming truth-telling by bidders, but sincere bidding is not an optimal strategy for bidders. In [6], we modified the payment rule of LSAA to make it truthful. In [5], we have supposed that the available quantity of LSA spectrum allows to split it into several blocks and we have proposed an efficient one-shot auction mechanism. In this paper, we again suppose that the auctioned LSA spectrum is composed of K identical blocks, but contrary to the mentioned previous mechanisms which were sealed-bid one-shot auctions, we focus on “ascending auctions” where information is revealed by bidders during some convergence phase. Ascending auctions have been used with great success to auction spectrum and they are preferred to sealed-bid auctions [8]. Indeed, ascending auctions have several advantages over one-shot schemes: they preserve the privacy of the winning bidder(s) because the winner(s) do(es) not need to reveal their valuation. Also, they give bidders the opportunity to adjust their valuations over the convergence phase. This benefit of price discovery is ignored in one-shot auctions, which assume that each bidder perfectly knows his valuations. Another advantage is transparency: each bidder sees the evolution of the auction and may adapt his bidding strategy. There are several types of ascending auction mechanisms. In this paper, we base our contributions on two existing mechanisms that achieve the outcome of the Vickrey-Clarke-Groves (VCG) auction [7, 10, 17], known to be jointly truthful and efficient (the total value extracted from the resource is maximal): the model from Mishra and Parkes [15] uses the new concept of “Universal Competitive Equilibrium” (UCE) and applies to general valuations (items may be different), while the “clinching” mechanism developed by Ausubel [1] and detailed in Section 4.2 applies to identical items. The rest of the paper is organized as follows: In Section 2 we present those two mechanisms. Section 3 introduces our LSA model, and Section 4 presents our first contributions, namely adaptations of the UCE (U-LSA) and the clinching mechanisms (C-LSA) to the LSA context, i.e., encompassing spectrum reusability. We then show in Section 5 that each of those mechanisms has a one-shot auction equivalent, which helps us establish some key properties. Finally, the performance of those schemes is compared through simulations in Section 6, and we conclude and give some directions for future work in Section 7. The contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows: 
 We adapt the UCE auction to the LSA context (taking into account spectrum reusability), and highlight some computational complexity issues with the resulting mechanism (U-LSA), even when auctioned items (spectrum blocks) are identical. To deal with the computational complexity of UCE, we propose to adapt the clinching approach by proposing a new ascending mechanism which we call C-LSA. We propose a new one-shot mechanism that is equivalent to C-LSA, and use it to establish some properties of C-LSA in terms of truthfulness and revenue guarantees. We compare U-LSA with C-LSA through simulations, by comparing their equivalent one-shot versions, and show that C-LSA yields in most cases much larger revenues (with a multiplicative factor between 5 and 10) for a very limited cost in terms of resource usage efficiency (around 4%). Hence we think our proposed mechanism C-LSA is a viable candidate for LSA spectrum allocation and pricing applied in a wireless 5G network.

Journal Name: NETNOMICS: Economic Research and Electronic Networking
Title: Drivers of COVID-19 vaccinations: vaccine delivery and delivery efficiency in the United States
Intro: The recent rollouts of coronavirus vaccines in many nations (and some others in development), coupled with the increasing infection cases/deaths from the disease, has added public- and political pressures to the expedited and widespread dissemination of the vaccines. Even the business sector has recently become concerned with sluggish vaccine rollout due to adverse implications for the speed of economic recovery.Footnote 1 This heightened interest has resulted in greater scrutiny of the rollout process, with some initial reports of inefficiency and mismanagement emerging.Footnote 2 Some nations have been better than others in vaccinating their populations; for example, Israel’s dexterity in vaccinating its population has received positive reviews.Footnote 3 While the institutional, economic, and geo-political factors vary substantially across nations, (and they might explain key reasons behind vaccination differences),Footnote 4 it is more surprising, even troubling, when subnational governments within a union exhibit substantial differences in vaccine rollouts. In the US, some states have been much better than others at vaccinating their populations, while others have lagged, sometimes due to no apparent reasons.Footnote 5 Some reports have sensed a lack of transparency behind a failure to understand differences in vaccinations across jurisdictions.Footnote 6 However, before any corrective policy measures can be undertaken, a good understanding of the factors driving vaccinations across US states is essential. It is towards that goal this paper is focused. Although new information about vaccination efficiency and coverage is literally emerging every day, it seems useful, both from an academic and a policy perspective, to analyze the available information in terms of the identification of bottlenecks in vaccinations. What are the significant factors driving the delivery of vaccines? Are the determinants of vaccine delivery different from the drivers of vaccine delivery efficiency? In this respect, we examine both the dissemination or diffusion of vaccines (vaccines actually administered) and the efficiency in their delivery (what percentage of vaccines that a state received were actually administered) during the early stages of the vaccine rollout in the US. Given the gravity of the underlying health and economic consequences surrounding the pandemic, the speed and spread of vaccinations are of paramount importance both to the public and the policymakers. An identification of significant factors facilitating vaccinations and promoting the efficiency of vaccinations would be useful information not only for jurisdictions where vaccinations are underway but also in areas that are looking to start vaccinating their populations. Some literature on the economic aspects of the pandemic has emerged, examining various aspects (see, for examples, Alfano and Ercolano [1], Asongu et al. [2], Baldwin and Weder di Mauro [3], Farzanegan et al. [7], Goel et al. [10], Goel and Nelson [12], Persad et al. [15], Price and van Holm [17], Roccato et al. [18], Salvatore et al. [19]). This paper adds initial formal research to the success of ongoing efforts to combat the COVID-19 pandemic by examining the drivers of the administration and delivery efficiency of coronavirus vaccines in the early stages of the vaccination campaign in the US. For this purpose, we use data from the 50 US states and place the formal analysis in the context of socio-economic drivers of vaccinations. Results show that state-economic prosperity and rural population aid both vaccine administration and delivery efficiency. Furthermore, more populous states have a weaker record for both outcome measures, at least in the early stages of the vaccine rollout campaign. Delivery efficiency improves in states with more nursing homes per capita, in states with more COVID-19 deaths, and those with more health workers. On the other hand, vaccination efficiency was lower in states with a centralized public health agency. States with a larger share of the elderly population and those with Democrats as governors were no different from others with regard to vaccinations. Finally, a state’s legacy of corrupt activity is broadly consistent with the greasing effects of corruption in improving vaccine administration and delivery efficiency. Some policy implications based on the evolving data are discussed in the concluding remarks. The structure of the rest of the paper includes the model in the next section, followed by data and estimation, results, and conclusions.

Journal Name: NETNOMICS: Economic Research and Electronic Networking
Title: A revisit of fixed and mobile broadband diffusion in the OECD: a new classification
Intro: Broadband communications lie at the heart of any developing information and digital society. Widespread broadband diffusion encourages innovation, contributes to productivity and economic growth. Fixed broadband (whether it is DSL or fiber) is defined as transmission capacity with sufficient bandwidth to permit the combined provision of voice, data, and video through a fixed line. Mobile broadband provided by 3G and 4G mobile systems supports today similar data transport rates, turning it into a very competitive technology. Today, broadband networks are an essential enabling infrastructure and technology adapted in all modern knowledge-based economies. As broadband becomes a commodity in households, it still enables the digitization of adopting sectors including energy, health, education, manufacturing and financial services leading to smarter societies with easier and more efficient information exchange and processing. Despite the overall rapid growth of broadband diffusion, many countries are still in the dilemma between fixed and mobile broadband deployment. Government authorities and regulators had to assess and develop policy strategies or even spectrum availability to promote faster adoption and services’ bundling based on demand. There are still many countries that rely heavily on fixed broadband and fiber networks where others manage to deploy usually first fixed and then mobile broadband in various time plans and penetration rates. Although there is significant literature on fixed broadband diffusion, there are still very few empirical studies examining the important and influential factors of fixed and mobile broadband diffusion with the Gompertz model. As the results are not always consistent, there is no empirical OECD broadband study yet to our knowledge, and since mobile broadband deployment took off during the past decade, investigating the effects and countries’ behaviors. We managed to collect a complete dataset since the very early diffusion of technology per year and study the OECD countries’ behavior, which we believe adds value to the paper’s methodology and results. Thus, the aim of this paper is to investigate the broadband technologies’ behaviors and their performance over time in the OECD area. It is interesting to examine heterogeneous and symmetric effects across our sample data and also estimate and compare the Gompertz model’s variables, saturation and inflection time, per country and per technology. As such, applying the Gompertz growth curve among other models suggested in the literature, in a time series dataset, we compare different groups of countries based on the stage of innovation. We find that although the diffusion time is similar for both technologies, the mobile broadband diffusion’s inflection time is asymmetric over the symmetric fixed broadband. The adoption time is almost double compared to the fixed, revealing a strong preference mostly of the developed countries on fixed broadband technology. Although OECD countries have been categorized into five groups based on the stage of innovation and Roger’s theory, only three of these groups agree with Roger’s categorization. The paper is organized as follows: Section 2 summarizes the existing literature on OECD studies, fixed and mobile communications diffusion, Section 3 presents the research methodology with the data, the model and the classification method, Section 4 presents the empirical results and Section 5 conclusions and Section 6 some suggestions on future work.

Journal Name: NETNOMICS: Economic Research and Electronic Networking
Title: Techno-economic price-worthiness of mobile networks: a hedonic heuristic perspective
Intro: In the context of long-term evolution (LTE) of modern wireless networks, a rational strategy to prescribe an apt performance measure on mobile services and platforms that support smart-devices (concurrent to traditional feature (cell) phones), warrants a comprehensive model. Traditionally, tariff-related parameters in conjunction with technology-specific details are regarded as appropriate candidates towards prescribing a cohesive performance metric thereof, while comparing services rendered by telecommunication companies (telcos) in related mobile operations. Mostly, such performance comparisons of mobile services are done on the basis of visible technology-dictated features (such as the speed of wireless traffic in bps); and, the underlying mobile networks are comparatively assessed by ranking them in terms of being the “fastest network” attribute in the service area considered. Correspondingly, a mobile speed index (MSI) is prescribed and explained in [31,32,33,34,35,36]. Sparsely included however, in such performance evaluations are inherent economics-related facts and productivity enhancement considerations (as a result of mobile device usage) relevant to services areas across the periods of assessment. As such, an expanded scope of performance assessment has been specified via a relative techno-economic performance index (RTPI) as proposed by the authors elsewhere in [23]. The present study offers yet an extended level of performance comparison of mobile services by including hedonic heuristics and associated price-worthiness aspects of such services, which are cast as overlay information upon MSI and RTPI considerations; hence, an appropriate measure of performance is proposed and named, the hedonic pricing index (HPI). It is based on the so-called hedonic heuristics, which is adopted in distinct market assessments of a variety of goods and services [2,3,4, 8,9,10,11, 13, 14, 16,17,18,19,20, 30, 38, 39, 42]; and, it is considered here towards assessing the performance of mobile services, (specifically, in the contexts of those supporting the co-diffusion of smart- and feature-devices). Hence, included in framing the said HPI are considerations pertinent to a preferential or ‘choosy’ attitude of subscribers (depicting the hedonic mindset) vis-à-vis their willingness-to-pay (WP) (if necessary even more!) for certain dedicated service profiles of their choice. The HPI prescription is also consistent with the eventual tariff scheme adopted by service providers matching their willingness-to-accept (WA) strategy implicated by return-on-investment (RoI) and other budget constraints. The underlying motivational considerations, as well as the scope of the present study is presented prior to such HPI-specific analysis. Accordingly, this paper is structured as follows: In the following section (Section 2), a review on modern mobile networks as they prevail in the context of LTE is presented. Then, the background details in assessing relative performance of such mobile networks in terms of MSI and RTPI parameters (as indicated in [23]) is briefly outlined in Section 3. Further, commensurate with the proposed method of adopting hedonic heuristics in prescribing the price-worthiness attribute to services rendered (in a specific service area) and deducing thereof the HPI under discussion, a basic tutorial is presented in Section 4 on hedonic concepts; and, Section 5 outlines the methodology of evaluating the HPI. Further, compiling relevant data towards computing and ascertaining the results on MSI, RTPI and HPI vis-à-vis an exemplary set of wireless networks and services is outlined in Section 6. Discussions on the proposed considerations and the obtained results are depicted in Section 7; hence, the foreseeable limitations of hedonic aspects of HPI modeling and price-worthiness in specifying the performance of mobile networks and services are identified and discussed. Further, the computed details pertinent to the relative performance of mobile networks are cross-verified against actual prices levied by incumbent mobile operators in a test service area over a known period of time. Lastly, the observed details are rationally considered with conclusive remarks in Section 8.

Journal Name: NETNOMICS: Economic Research and Electronic Networking
Title: Economic replicability tests: an “out-of-the-box” implementation
Intro: The Digital Agenda for Europe (DAE) is one of the seven flagship initiatives under Europe 2020, a strategy that is aimed at delivering growth by reaping the full benefits of digital technologies. This initiative has established ambitious targets for the EU as a whole in terms of broadband speeds. In particular, by 2020 all households should have been able to benefit from a fast broadband subscription of 30 Mbps or higher and 50% of the households to take up subscriptions of 100 Mbps or higher. Unfortunately, in terms of ultra-fast broadband subscriptions only 26% of the European homes subscribe to at least 100 Mbps and 50% to at least 30 Mbps speeds, respectively [24]. Such figures indicate a rather unsatisfactory roll-out in relation to EU’s 2020 targets. This can be attributed to EU’s regulatory environment the main principles of which constitute a crucial determinant for achieving DAE goals in terms of connectivity improvement. Unfortunately, these are not always aligned with market developments and trends and sometimes refrain from providing telecommunications operators with the appropriate investment incentives relative to super-fast broadband infrastructure deployment [7]. The importance of high-speed broadband and the benefits it brings has been acknowledged in the literature in terms of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth ([40, 19, 33, 8, 41]), productivity ([56, 57, 11, 10]), job creation ([17, 18, 29, 42]) and consumer surplus [4]. Given that, the EC released Recommendation 2013/466/EU on consistent non-discrimination obligations and costing methodologies for the promotion of competition and the enhancement of the broadband investment environment [23]. Its objective is to reconcile competition and investment via allowing for flexibility in the pricing of new wholesale NGANs products, while ensuring stable wholesale copper access prices. The Recommendation, among others, introduces the concept of the Economic Reliability Test (ERT). The latter has in view, according to recital 62 of the Recommendation, to “…ensure, in combination with the other competitive safeguards introduced such as EoI,Footnote 1 the technical replicability test, and a demonstrable retail price constraint resulting from a copper anchor or alternative infrastructures, that SMPFootnote 2 operators do not abuse this pricing flexibility to exclude potential competitors from the market”. The test itself assesses “…whether the margin between the retail price of the relevant retail product and the price of the relevant NGA-based regulated wholesale input covers the incremental downstream costs and a reasonable percentage of common costs” [23, p. 31]. Furthermore, the Recommendation also suggests that the profitability of flagship products should be measured on the basis of a DCF approach. Also, it has taken a keen interest in employing the Equally Efficient Operator (EEO) standard to demonstrate whether the incumbent’s retail arm can trade profitably if charged the same price as its competitors by the incumbent’s wholesale arm. Recital 64 advocates that the usage of EEO standard “…enables NRAsFootnote 3 to support the SMP operator’s investments in NGA networks and provides incentives for innovation in NGA-based services” [17, p.20]. On top of that the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (BEREC) followed by issuing guidelines for NRAs on how an ERT should be conducted in practice [5]. Another report was prepared for the European Telecommunications Network Operators (ETNO)‘s association by the Charles River Associates (CRA) consulting firm pertinent to ERT. It recommended a consistent and proportionate approach regarding the parameters and procedures of the ERT after analyzing both the Recommendation 2013/466/EU and BEREC guidelines in the context of NGANs service provision [14]. In academic literature, Jaunaux and Lebourges [39] were the first to discuss the issue of ERT implementation, followed by Charalampopoulos et al. [13] who examined the impact of a possible deviation from Net Neutrality (NN) rules in the EU on ERT conduct. Results of Jaunaux and Lebourges [39] showed that reconciliation between investment and competition can be achieved under certain hypotheses: First, the wholesale access price is seen as a two-part tariff comprising from a fixed-part, invariable to the volume of access, and a variable part which depends upon the number of subscribers. Second, only the latter is included in the ERT. In other words, the fixed-part is omitted from calculations. To support their claim, the authors used a simplified but representative numerical example based on a Fiber-to-the-Home (FttH) investment opportunity to illustrate that conducting an ERT using a DCF method which includes the fixed-part of the wholesale access price in the calculation process could deliver a negative result. Such outcome implies that the investor operator is engaged in a foreclosure strategy, even if no form of discrimination is taking place whatsoever. This paper investigates in a NGAN infrastructure investment scenario i) the impact the absence/presence of long-term access pricing agreements can have on ERT conduct and ii) possible ROT incorporation in ERT implementation. The goal is to examine whether it is possible not to omit the fixed part of the wholesale access price from calculations and at the same time improve ERT results obtained via the use of the DCF approach. ROT usage in telecommunications regulation has exhibited a focus primarily on risk premium (e.g., [21, 50, 15]) and the option to delay (e.g., [20, 47, 48, 9, 30]), and secondarily on other issues such as the timing of an investment decision and the setting of regulated access prices (see [12, 34]). The organization of the article is as follows. Section 2 provides a short overview of ROT usage in telecommunications regulation so far. Section 3 presents the ERT methodology and implements it in the absence/presence of long-term access pricing agreements. Then it is examined how Real Options (ROs) can be incorporated in the DCF approach. Section 4 discusses the obtained results whereas Sect. 5 provides the concluding remarks of the article with a review of its main results.

Journal Name: NETNOMICS: Economic Research and Electronic Networking
Title: Nexus between telecommunication infrastructures, defence and economic growth: a global evidence
Intro: As the world is becoming more telecom and information and communication technology (ICT)-dependent, almost all the sectors of the economy use the telecommunication services/products to achieve their aims and objectives. For example, telecommunications infrastructure could either influence the demand for, and supply of transportation services through its electronic impulses [59, 77]. A relatively vast number of empirical studies has highlighted the significant role that telecommunication infrastructures/ICT play in promoting economic growth and development in the literature (inter alia: [24, 25, 27, 30, 47, 48, 53, 61, 64, 80, 90, 106, 117, 119, 120]). Slightly over a century, after Graham Bell's invention of the telephone in 1876, the telephone and other developed modes of telecommunication have reached almost every part of modern society as a new medium of telecommunication technology [27]. The examples of spectrum of telecommunications infrastructure services that serve the modern society/sectors of the economy include: voice over Internet protocol (VoIP) technology; setup of standard telephone systems and data networks; radio antenna testing; installation of optical fibers; soft switches; site location for the cell tower; media gateways; mobile portals; billing and mediation systems; and general packet radio service (GPRS) technology [27]. They are most often provided by the Internet service providers (ISP), satellite companies, and phone companies. The services provided by the telecommunications/ICT industry facilitate investment, industrial and economic activities and this is because they help to reduce the cost of transaction [83, 92]. Apart from the importance of telecommunications infrastructure services/ICT to economic activities, it could also play a cogent role in strengthening and improving security against present and potential future attacks by identifying potential threats, aiding information sharing, providing mechanisms to safeguard nations, and developing response capabilities. Since the telecommunications infrastructure services/ICT is used by the defence personnel/sector across the world there is need to investigate the role it plays in the defence sector. As the defence sector is managed and maintained by the governments across the world through defence spending, there are also efforts by governments to integrate telecommunications infrastructure services/ICT into military/defence operations. This is evident because the defence sector is involved in ICT-related analytical capabilities, extensive networks of sensors, control, command, programming etc. that provide information directly to the warfighter and to smart weaponry on an immediate and real-time basis. In this study, in order to capture the role that telecommunications infrastructure plays in the defence/military sector, the defence/military sector is measured by defence spending. This is because according to Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI) (2020) defence spending “refers to all government spending on current military forces and activities, including salaries and benefits, operational expenses, arms and equipment purchases, military construction, research and development, and central administration, command and support”. Also, since the establishment of SIPRI in 1966, the organisation has not failed to be a reliable source of data on defence spending for the world. The SIPRI defence spending database has been used widely by researchers and scholars in different fields to examine/discuss a wide variety of relevant issues related to the defence sector [58]. In the light of multiple circumstances and factors, the government demand for defence spending is usually on the basis of providing security (both external and internal) for economic activities. And that is why national security is the most significant consequence of defence spending [110]. Theoretically, there are three basic channels by which defence spending could be linked to growth, namely, demand, supply, security channels [58]. These channels help to theorise the potential effects of defence spending/sector on growth, which could either be positive, negative or no relation. Studies have extensively examined the relationship between defence spending and growth without reaching a conclusion on the direction relationship that exists between them. And that is why the debate on the nexus between the two variables and other macroeconomic variables still remains an ongoing one [29, 94,95,96,97, 100]. The reasons behind differences in results and conclusions from the previous studies in the literature could be linked to the application of different econometric methods, theories, sample periods etc. The results on the defence spending-growth nexus for cross-country and specific country studies could generally be grouped into positive, negative and negligible outcomes (inter alia: [23, 28, 34, 36, 37, 49, 57]). Although most of the previous studies tend to support the negative effect of defence spending on growth, which points to the growth retarding nature of the spending when it is not well utilised [57]. The lack of consensus in the literature concerning the defence spending-growth nexus calls for further investigation by taking into account the role that telecommunication infrastructures/ICT plays. Previous studies have considered: (i) the role that investment, stock market, trade openness, poverty and inequality, employment etc. plays in the nexus between defence spending and growth (inter alia: [58, 111, 116]); and (ii) the knowledge economy effects of formal institutions, entrepreneurship, globalization, peace and stability etc. (see, for example, Andrés et al. [5], Asongu and Tchamyou [11], Amavilah et al. [4], Tchamyou [113] among others). Meanwhile, the role that telecommunication infrastructures play in the nexus between defence spending (proxy for defence sector) and growth has suffered neglect in the literature. To the best of our knowledge, this study is the first to investigate the telecommunication infrastructures impact on defence spending-growth nexus. Filling this gap in the existing literature is important because: (i) as insecurity is ravaging different parts of the world, telecommunications policies need to be defence sector/security-friendly; (ii) according to Choudhary et al. [22], the key factors that could contribute to telecommunication infrastructural/ICT development include defence spending, per-capita gross domestic product (GDP) etc., which could be adequately utilised for the war against insecurity in countries worldwide; (iii) defence spending could have technology spin-off effects on other sectors and possible security externalities; and (iv) the unavoidable defence/security challenges that tend to lead to the eventual destruction of lives, assets and the environment requires a comprehensive approach through the effective use of telecommunications infrastructure services/ICT. Given the multifaceted role that telecommunication infrastructures/ICT play across all the sectors of the economy, this study contributes to the literature in the following ways: (i) by examining the defence sector growth nexus of telecommunication infrastructure for 157 countries spanning from 2000 to 2018. As mentioned earlier, to measure the defence sector, defence spending serves as the proxy, while growth is measured by the real gross domestic product, and telecommunication infrastructures are measured by a composite index of telecommunication (which is comprised of mobile line, fixed line, and internet access penetration) via a principal component method; (ii) according to Saba [98], defence spending can bring about some possible differences in its economic impact among countries because of the productive structural base and development levels. We herein disaggregate our data into four income groups based on the World Bank classification of the world's economiesFootnote 1. We have the following reasons for classifying the panel data into four income levels. First, we have a dataset including 157 countries, which lets each subpanel contain enough data to test. Second, investigating telecommunication infrastructures-defence spending-growth nexus for countries within the same income level will reveal the direction of causality among our variables for a more homogenous group of countries that may have relatively more homogenous economic or socioeconomic and political behaviours. Third, the different results obtained will give the opportunity to compare the relationship between telecommunication infrastructures, defence spending and growth for the income groups. Consequently, the critical question of whether one size really fits all in terms of the causality between telecommunication infrastructures, defense spending and economic growth may also be investigated; (iii) Unlike the previous studies, this paper utilises the most recent Abrigo and Love [1] proposed GMM estimator panel causality test. Their novel panel causality test addresses problems of endogeneity via instrumentation in the panel-VAR model. According to Nickell [82], when the lagged dependent variable is used as a regressor, the panel-VAR model estimates appear to be biased. But Abrigo and Love [1] argue that in the presence of a lagging dependent variable as a regressor, the GMM estimator will yield consistent estimates in a panel-VAR model. Hence, the reason why we use their panel causality approach to achieve the objective of this paper. The remaining sections of this study follow this order. In Section 2 we review related literature; Section 3 presents methodology and data sources; Section 4 presents the empirical results and discussion; and Section 5 concludes with policy implications.

Journal Name: NETNOMICS: Economic Research and Electronic Networking
Title: ICT diffusion and climate change: The role of economic growth, financial development and trade openness
Intro: Information and communication technology (ICT) has emerged as a wonder over the past three decades as it has contributed to different aspects of economic development and structural changes. Although, the economic dimensions of ICT are well researched, the environmental aspects are usually ignored. However, in this digital age, CO2 emissions are a global challenge, and they go beyond the national borders. Therefore, it is critical to investigate the climatic implications of ICT for a global panel of developing and developed countries while addressing the climate change challenges. ICT is a special case of technologies that assists in more innovations and encourages economic performance. ICT diffusion initiates new business opportunities which encourage the competitiveness of an industry and stimulates investment in different sectors of the economy. Quah [35] explains that ICT overcomes time and space constraints, accelerates the delivery of information and reduces information asymmetry. Moreover, ICT improves health outcomes, labor skills, market transparency, financial transactions and an efficient allocation of resources [20, 26, 29, 33, 37]. On the other hand, financial development (FD) is regarded as an important ingredient of economic growth [10]. The financial sector acts as a link between the deficit and surplus sectors of the economy. In addition, the financial sector mobilizes funds, reduces transaction costs, promotes inter-industry transactions and distributes resources into the highest productive investments [37]. Schumpeter [41] discusses that the development of the financial sector increases the efficiency of resource distribution while Raheem and Oyinlola [36] explain that FD enhances mobilization, utilization, and monitoring of funds. It is believed that FD upgrades material and human capital accumulation, brings about allocative efficiency and leads to higher levels of economic development [9, 29, 42, 43]. Recently, there has been substantial development in the financial sector which is closely linked with ICT diffusion. The financial sector has spent more than US$197 billion on ICT products and services in 2014 [10]. In addition, the financial sector is the single largest buyer of ICT products and services ever since the 1990s. Since the 1980s, the development of the financial sector has been based on the transmission of digital information. ICT facilitates financial access by reducing the cost of marketing and enhances market participation by decreasing information asymmetry [10]. Moreover, ICT supports competition among financial institutions and significantly improves their operating efficiency. It is suggested that ICT may further enhance the development of the financial sector. For example, internet usage reduces processing, information, and transaction costs and accelerates investment activities. Therefore, it is believed that the further usage of ICT appliances and communication devices in the financial sector may expand access to credit facilities, broaden the export base, ensure a more efficient allocation and monitoring of resources as well as substantiate financial inclusion [37, 43]. While ICT plays an important role in economic and FD, it also influences CO2 emissions. In addition, carbon dioxide emissions are identified as the primary source of climate change. However, the carbon implications of ICT are yet unsettled [1, 26, 33]. The relationship between ICT and CO2 emissions remained complicated because ICT exhibits differential impacts on carbon dioxide emissions. The ICT optimizes production processes, improves energy efficiency and reduces emission intensity which negativelyFootnote 1 impacts (i.e. reduces) CO2 emissions. In contrast, the ICT sector consumes large amounts of energy during production, processing, installation and distribution of ICT products which positively influence (i.e. increases) CO2 emissions. Therefore, the ICT has diverse impacts on CO2 emissions [37]. On the other hand, the financial sector has a deeper and wider application of ICT as compared to many other sectors. Actually, the financial sector is the largest consumer of ICT products and it focuses on the expansion of ICT infrastructure [10]. Now, an important question arises: Does FD influence CO2 emissions positively or negatively? Notably, if the usage of ICT products in the financial sector leads to energy efficiency, it will negatively impact CO2 emissions. Instead, ICT may boost FD but poor environmental conditions may also arise from the usage of ICT products in the financial sector, if ICT products consume large amounts of energy. Unfortunately, the carbon implications of FD are rarely focused. Therefore, the exact effects of FD on CO2 emissions are difficult to ascertain and need further investigation [33, 43]. In the presence of ambiguity, an investigation of the relationship among ICT diffusion, FD and CO2 emissions is relevant for this study. Although there are a few studies that investigate the relationship among ICT diffusion, FD and CO2 emissions, there are some gaps in the existing literature. Firstly, the results are inconclusive whether ICT and FD improve or degrade environmental quality [33, 37, 43]. Secondly, the impact of ICT is usually studied with one indictor while the ICT index has not yet been studied comprehensively along with FD and trade openness. Thirdly, most of the earlier studies have used panel data models which generally did not account for the problems of cross-sectional dependence and endogeneity [26]. It may be one of the reasons for the inconclusive results of the earlier studies. These gaps motivate us for the further analysis of carbon implications of ICT. Hence, the present study explores the effects of ICT, FD and trade openness on CO2 emissions for a global sample of 92 countries covering the period from 1990 to 2018. We employ alternative panel data estimation techniques such as pooled ordinary least squares (POLS), the fixed effect model (FEM) and system generalized method of moments (SGMM) with panel corrected standard errors to address the cross-sectional dependence and endogeneity issues. Mainly, our study contributes in the context of the 21st conference of the Parties to the Climate Convention (Paris Agreement or COP21) and Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) which put emphasis on the mitigation of climate change. Moreover, the empirical investigation of carbon implications of ICT in developing countries is scarce in the literature. Therefore, our focus is a global sample which includes developed as well as developing countries. Furthermore, we construct an index of ICT with the principal component analysis (PCA) to better understand the climatic consequences of ICT. The study is structured as follows: Section 2 studies the relevant literature on ICT, FD, trade openness and CO2 emissions. Section 3 discusses the methodological framework for the analysis while Section 4 describes the data and construction of the variables. Section 5 reports and analyses the estimation results. Lastly, Section 6 concludes the study with some policy recommendations.

Journal Name: NETNOMICS: Economic Research and Electronic Networking
Title: A stock options metaphor for content delivery networks
Intro: Nowadays, the adoption of CDNs is standard practice for many content-generating entities. The population of OSs is constantly increasing with content that becomes multimedia-richer, “heavier,” and, structurally, far more complex. In this evolving ecosystem, we aim to rationalize the reservation and use of CDN resources from both the OS (client) and the CDN perspectives. The use of CDN resources needs to be carefully planned in the space-time domains. The CDN gradually shifts its attention to more fine-grained resource management schemes that minimize overheads (unused capacity, etc.). Schemes and techniques for more accurate resource claims are of common interest as they positively impact the involved clients (OSs) and the CDN operator/provider. Resource utilization can be maximized and, thus, advance the pertinent economy in total (i.e., improve the position of both sellers and buyers). CDN providers can deliver better services to a broader audience at more competitive prices. Furthermore, improving resource utilization may result in the reduction of network congestion. We adopt an improved framework for the methodical management of CDN resources. Specifically, we borrow concepts and techniques from the capital market [37, 58, 62, 63]. We treat the CDN resources (assets) as (capital) stocks. The stockholders are the content-generating organizations (OSs). According to the client needs for resources, stocks are purchased dynamically, aiming to sustain the experienced visitor load efficiently. The CDN monitors the incoming traffic of each client and learns the temporal distribution of their resource use (bandwidth) to protect against resource οver/under-use. This knowledge is of utmost importance for the rationalization of CDN resource management. Using the proposed LPM, the CDN then establishes load predictions for the immediate future to reserve resources for the OS well beforehand and, thus, cope with the fluctuating load. Resources can be claimed from the CDN but also traded among clients (Fig. 1). A tool for trading CDN resources, which improves the resilience of the LPM to forecasting failures, is the capital SM. CDN resources are traded in the SM by the actual proprietors (i.e., clients that have already acquired resources but experience load incompatible with their expectations/predictions). Basic framework structure This paper introduces another tool that further improves the forecasting and resource trading mechanisms’ resilience, the capital SOs. According to CDN predictions, each OS buys SOs at prices and for the duration specified by models such as that of Black-Scholes (BS) [37], Barone-Adesi & Whaley [3], Bjerksund & Stensland [8], Ju & Zhong [38], and Binomial and Trinomial Trees [19]. These SOs are exercised if and when needed (i.e., if an OS runs out of resources at the end of the billing period and cannot locate any available surplus in the SM). Overall, this resource management scheme (Fig. 1) is essential for CDN providers that “lease” finite resources (bandwidth) from other operators. The latter stakeholders (higher-level entities) constitute a meta-level in the CDN ecosystem (meta-CDN). We access the performance of the proposed scheme using extensive real traces taken from high traffic OSs, such as chambers of commerce, universities, popular sports content websites, and e-commerce websites. Our findings show that the introduction of the SOs enables the proposed framework to further “absorb” forecasting failures and optimize CDN resource management. We compare the proposed framework with other plans currently being used in the market. We argue that this capital market metaphor is a well-suited option for structuring the modern World Wide Web (WWW) ecosystem. The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 discusses the related work and Sect. 3 presents the architecture of the proposed framework. Section 4 describes current CDN pricing policies on the market. Section 5 deals with the simulations we choose to perform, describes their related parameters and discusses the corresponding metrics and results. Finally, Sect. 6 concludes the paper and discusses future work.

Journal Name: NETNOMICS: Economic Research and Electronic Networking
Title: Correlative and asymmetric effects of information technology on capital flows
Intro: The rapid pace of growth in information technology (IT) has been acknowledged worldwide. While developed countries of North America, Western Europe, and Asia are driving their economies with sophisticated and advanced technology, most developing countries seem to be lagging behind, due to their inability to invent high technology. They are, therefore, largely dependent on the acquisition of already invented technology from the developed countries. In particular, African countries rely heavily on imported IT to enhance production, industrialization, and economic growth. IT facilitates capital flows, hence African countries are willing to embrace and use it to attract more inflows. These countries, within limits of their financial capacity, are striving to adopt and utilize the latest IT, for the purpose of driving economic growth and development. IT is generally acclaimed to be a vital facilitator of capital flows across the globe, particularly to developing countries. Most countries in Africa, Asia, and Eastern Europe, depend on capital inflows to sustain economic growth and development. Capital flows come in different forms, and may be unstable, and sometimes volatile. The foreign direct investment component of capital flows is considered to be relatively more stable than other components. The foreign portfolio investment component, on the other hand, is more liquid and unstable, due to its high responsiveness towards unfavourable economic conditions. Its impact on economic growth is, therefore, favourable in the short-run, but could turn out to be largely unfavourable in the long-run, due to its volatility [40]. The other components are more stable, and characterized by less volatility. Generally, capital flow is important to developing countries, due to the wide resource gap that tends to slow economic growth and development. Domestic resources are grossly inadequate to facilitate rapid economic growth. This is probably the main reason behind the tendency of some developing countries to accumulate exceedingly high levels of external debt. Over the last two decades, there has been a tremendous progress in the adoption of advanced IT in developing countries, which has accounted in no small measure, for the increasing trend of capital inflows with positive impact on growth and development. The capital inflows have also been greatly encouraged by the political and economic reforms that took place in most of the countries, which created conducive environment for advanced countries to supply more resources to underdeveloped countries. The countries, with such conducive environment, have so far succeeded in attracting more foreign direct investment, foreign portfolio investment, foreign loans, and foreign development aid. The political and economic reforms undertaken in these countries thus made them major recipients of capital flows. However, the increasing role of IT in global capital flows seems to have attracted more interest and attention of researchers in recent times. In previous research on this issue, the rush to package the relationship between IT and capital flows left some vital aspects unattended. These studies investigated only the direct effect of IT on capital flows, ignoring the fact that IT has more elaborate effects on capital flows. This is an important gap that needs to be filled, in order to make estimation results more relevant to policy making. Furthermore, the components of capital flows deserve investigation to ascertain the level of asymmetric effects generated by IT. The need to conduct further research on the issue, at this time, cannot be overemphasized, bearing in mind that IT can impact capital flows and the components in a more elaborate form (directly, indirectly and asymmetrically). The direct impact is transmitted straight from IT to capital flows. On the other hand, indirect effects pass through variables such as rate of return on capital, exchange rate, financial innovation, and size of the private sector. These are variables that are closely linked to IT, and also help to multiply its effect on capital flows. Again, IT can impact asymmetrically by generating uneven effects on aggregate capital flows and the various components (foreign direct investment, foreign portfolio investment, foreign debt flows, and official development aid). This study, therefore, attempts to estimate the correlative effects (direct and indirect) and asymmetric effects of IT on capital flows and the various components. This is done by building and estimating an appropriate model that has the capacity to capture the direct, indirect and asymmetric effects. The investigation is expected to fill the perceived gap in literature, and significantly contribute to the existing body of knowledge concerning IT and capital flows. The study employs the techniques of the general method of moments (GMM) to evaluate the various effects of IT on capital flows. In terms of scope, the study covers the ten most technologically advanced countries in Sub-Saharan Africa. The countries, according to the world ranking, are South Africa, Nigeria, Kenya, Mauritius, Ghana, Rwanda, Botswana, Angola, Uganda, and Zimbabwe [26]. The period of study is 1996-2019, as data on IT were unavailable before 1996. The remaining sections of this study comprise a literature review, descriptive analysis of IT and capital flows, model specification, estimation techniques, estimations and analysis of results, policy recommendations, and conclusion.

Journal Name: NETNOMICS: Economic Research and Electronic Networking
Title: Market interaction structure and equilibrium price heterogeneity in monopolistic competition
Intro: Price dispersion has been the subject of strong academic interest in recent decades. As standard general equilibrium models assuming perfect information yield competitive equilibria with competing producers/sellers setting identical prices, researchers have come up with approaches which are able to reproduce price dispersion as an equilibrium phenomenon [36]. The two main lines in this respect are either suggesting the extension of the standard monopolistic competition model or the use of a search-theoretic approach [10]. Along the first line, we can find heterogeneous marginal costs as the most trivial solution but also heterogeneous demand elasticities resulting from heterogeneous visiting costs [40]. The second line emphasizes that there is some incompleteness in price information on the side of consumers which is assumed to arise from positive search costs (see e.g. [11] for a comprehensive review of this literature). In this paper, we join to this vein of literature, but take an approach to consumer search and price heterogeneity from the viewpoint of complex systems. Instead of starting from a detailed account of how consumers are limited in attaining complete information, we rather take the structure of information flows as given and view this structure as a complex system of market interactions between producers/suppliers and consumers/buyers. As a result, we are able to infer on how the structure of the network connecting market actors shape price heterogeneity. Our approach from the side of complex systems is also supported by recent work which argues that the analysis of increasingly complex economic systems requires the integration of aspects and methods from the toolbox of complex system research [23, 24]. On the other hand, the results of network science indicate that the aggregate performance of a system is inherently related to the structure of connections among agents in the system (see e.g. [7, 16, 28, 34]). Several contributions have recently shown how economic micro-structure affects aggregate performance. Acemoglu et al. [2] and [1] e.g. demonstrate that the asymmetric distribution of intersectoral transactions can lead to heavy-tailed aggregate fluctuations. Other papers show that accounting for the structure of connections between market actors can significantly change predictions from standard economic models [5, 37, 38]. Further studies focus on connections between financial institutions and reveal that the structure of these connections contribute to systemic risk [3, 4, 19]. Some other studies have explicitly taken into account the relationship between network structure or network formation and the pricing behavior of firms. However, these contributions typically refer to network externalities where the connection structure is assumed to play a role between consumers [8, 30, 31, 33], to situations where firms can engage in some kind of information exchange [12] or markets where networks (like telecommunication networks) compete with each other [27]. Some of these contributions assume targeted pricing (price discrimination) on the side of producers, where consumer-specific pricing depends on the level of influence a given consumer has on others [21, 22], while network structure among consumers is taken into account in these papers. Other studies, like the authors in [43], have focused on pricing in supply chain networks, where the structure of interaction among production sites is explicit, but modeling the demand from outside the supply network remains limited. A relatively recent line of research focuses on network externalities from a structural perspective. These contributions explicitly consider the structure of network connections among consumers (local network externalities) and present how specific connection structures affect pricing behavior and may lead to market segmentation [6, 8, 13, 14, 18, 29]. A similar approach is followed by [41], who introduce explicit network structures among productive subsidiaries of decision making firms with strategic substitutability among the products of the subsidiaries. However, there is no attempt up to our knowledge which examines the role of explicit network structures between buyers and sellers, and how this structure affects price dispersion. Although by taking a different perspective, our model is a close relative to search-cost models, like [39] or [17], where consumers are not perfectly informed about all prices on the market. We introduce a specific version of a standard model of monopolistic competition with finite actors, where the interaction network among market actors is given explicitly and this network represents the biased information flows on the market. In this sense, this paper assumes some sort of biased information flows, represented by a specific network structure, and then continues to analyze the role of this structure in shaping price dispersion. This is in contrast with the standard approach where consumers are assumed to be aware of the true price index as made up of all prices in the market. Instead, our more realistic extension assumes that this information basis is selective and consumer-specific, which producers take into account when making their decisions. From a methodological point of view, our approach is similar to [42] and [41]: instead of assuming a given network structure, we also derive an existence condition without a fixed structure and then analyze the effect of some specific network arrangements using network models. Also, our approach builds on that of [38] by using the standard symmetric monopolistic competition model and develop it in a way that explicit supplier and buyer relationships are taken into account. The contribution of our paper with respect to these closely related papers is twofold. First, we analyze the explicit connection structure between suppliers and buyers while previous papers focused on network externalities between consumers (demand side) of given firm or subsidiaries (supply side). Thus, our results contribute to previous research by pointing to the effects of the connection structure between the supply and demand side. Second, it releases the implicit symmetry- and representativity condition used in [38] by allowing for arbitrary network structures within the same model framework of monopolistic competition. The paper is structured as follows. In the next section, we construct the model of optimal pricing, with an incomplete market interaction structure. The following section then derives the condition under which optimal pricing is possible and economically feasible. Then, a separate section is devoted to the analysis of the optimal price distribution under different assumptions about the structure of the market interaction network. First, we consider a complete network as a baseline case and then explore the properties of the price distribution if the network structure is symmetric (Erdős–Rényi type) and if it is asymmetric. We conclude the paper with a summary of the main results and pointing out some areas for further research.

Journal Name: NETNOMICS: Economic Research and Electronic Networking
Title: A bandwidth auction mechanism to enable affordable internet access
Intro:
The Millennium Development Goals articulated by the United Nations (UN) include the aim of making the benefits of new technologies available, particularly information and communications, in cooperation with the private sector [30]. Current data indicate that despite the strong progress in Internet penetration from 6% in 2000 to nearly 51% in 2019 [15], a growing gap exists between the adoption rates of rich and poor populations regardless of the ICT price basket monitored [16]. This condition has resulted in “a half of the people with 4G network coverage remain offline, mainly due to high costs of Internet access”. Previous experiences, for instance, of those in rural settings, recognize the necessity of a solid economic framework to balance the social goal of offering services to the poorest and the practical need for incentives for operators to provide services. Many studies, such as [4, 5, 18, 29], have shown that auctions are efficient mechanisms for dynamic resource allocation, particularly for selling bandwidth. Their promising results are partially explained because they can handle uncertainty, such as estimations of user demand functions, and dynamically control allocation through competition between users. Nevertheless, in scenarios where mixed buying-capacity users compete and tight resource constraints are common, it is expected that resources may only be allocated to users with higher budgets. To counteract this problem, the field of economics has started to study the benefits of subsidized and set-aside auctions for government procurement [2, 13, 25]. These mechanisms have previously been used to spread allocations favoring selected groups, such as small companies. In subsidy auction schemes, a selected group is granted a proportionally higher bid, such that members (i.e., low-budget users) can compete with those in nontargeted groups (i.e., high-budget users). In set-aside auction schemes, resources are preassigned to groups to ensure a minimal, guaranteed allocation within the group, while group members still compete with each other. Nevertheless, subsidy auction schemes include a number of pitfalls for selling bandwidth. First, it is not clear who is in charge of funding subsidies; second, to have a positive effect, the actual subsidy has to be set, which generally requires a previous study; third, the allocation of units to low-budget groups is not guaranteed; and fourth, this type of auction does not solve the problem of determining users who should be granted the subsidy. Set-aside schemes suffer almost the same problems, but their design offers an allocation guarantee. The adoption of a set-aside mechanism is complex in practice. Users cannot be easily clustered as belonging to a favored group, and higher budget users have the rational best response of adopting a lower budget role as lower prices are expected. Our work presents a pricing model that is oriented to reach the social goal of providing network access to all while simultaneously addressing these practical challenges. Our pricing strategy introduces a self-selection of users based on budget constraints, enabled by new networking technologies. Specifically, our contributions, sorted by importance, are as follows: 
 We present a social-goal-oriented auction mechanism that incentivizes users to reveal private information by providing rewards or assigning penalties, and thereby, reducing the probability of receiving allocated units. We present and discuss the trade-off of our auction mechanism between the increased network coverage of low-budget users and the decrease of operator’s income. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents a research overview in auction methods for bandwidth allocation as well as the similarities and differences between our approach and previous methods. Next, we present the target network deployment scenario and its main elements. In Section 4, we explain the proposed auction mechanism, starting with a simple auction of two units and three users and then generalize the auction to many users and quantities. In Section 5, we present an alternative to calculate the Nash equilibrium in an actual setting where many users are competing. In Section 6, we discuss the auction setup, introduce other mechanisms implemented for benchmarking, and explain the scenarios used for the simulations. Section 7 presents results that compare our proposed mechanism with other coverage-oriented mechanisms. Finally, Section 8 concludes this paper.
